description:
This was my first time eating Moroccan food so I'm not sure how authentic Khamsa is but regardless it tastes really good !!!

The place is really small, only a few tables but SUPER CUTE DECORS. There is one big table in the middle and we shared that table with another party but it wasn't too bad. You would feel very cozy but also boujee here. 

The service was really great. They were attentive, since the place is so small, you can always get their attention.  

The food is on the more expensive spectrum but the portion size is pretty decent. 

Lamb Couscous: very filling because it comes with lots of couscous. The lamb was very tender and the vegetable toppings and caramelized onions go really well together. It tops with caramelized onion so it tastes a bit sweet. But I like my food sweet so I would high recommend this dish. 

Mrouzia: The lamb WAS AMAZING. It's saffron honey so it is like a sweet and savory taste. If you dont like sweet flavor, don't order this. But it was very tender and flavorful. It comes with only lamb and like some dates... Not as a well rounded dish as the Lamb Couscous.

Fish Tagine: the Fish was tender and full of flavor. The fish piece was pretty huge too. And not dry at all. I was a bit hesitant to order fish, because most places dont cook fish right and it just smells but not here! 

I usually don't order lamb, because it tends to have a weird after taste. But I did not taste anything unpleasant in the lamb dishes here.
author: Veronica N.

description:
Food: 

Kafta 5/5 - great texture and flavor
Bastilla 3/5 - not the best one i've had. a bit too sweet and dry. after a few bites I didn't want to keep eating it
Chiflor 5/5 - super yummy
Tanjia 4/5 - flavors were delicious but the lamb, although tender, was a bit too fatty for our taste. Props on making it not taste lamby! The side vegetables were soooo good and melted in your mouth
Kunefe 5/5 - love kunefe and this one was super yummy

Service - some folks were nice

Ambiance - the patio area was nice
author: Laura D.

description:
Two stars because the waitress, while serving the most expensive meal of the menu (which was very small portioned) splattered oil on my new button down shirt and besides saying sorry and awkwardly offering to pay for my dry cleaning out of her own pocket (seriously?) did not even give any compensation or discount...
Did you really think I would take your, waitress money? Come on! Talk to your manager and ask to give a dessert or something!
The food was very expensive and the portions were not at all for share. It was really delicious food but this is kind of a bad joke that you are charging so much for food and barely give any.

My friends and I had a great time because we just did but I would definitely had more fun at a different place.
author: Hai C.

description:
Intimate environment. delicious food. good service.

We got too much food :)

* Merguez - sausage. Good, though not my favorite.
* Khamsa salad - crunchy kale with dates.
* Chicken Tagine - chicken was fall-off-the-bone. Figs were too sweet for my husband but I enjoyed them in moderation.
* Tajin - if you like Mole, this slow-cooked lamb dish has similar spices but it's more of a dry rub than a sauce. So good, even my 3-year old liked it (the next day)
* Couscous - spiced couscous with almond slivers and raisins. So good.
* Moroccan Mint Tea

FYI - The portions are generous!
author: J. F.

description: My friend open a secret to me and I want to open it to you.... shhh! This place is one of the best food I've EVER had! Morocco has never been so close as with tajine and the dates salad! As a plus: restaurant has a great atmosphere and ambience, it's like traveling there! You should try both lamb and beef tagine and will not for sure regret it'
author: Irina P.

description:
Note that my standard may be higher than average given that I worked in morocco for 6 months and had some spectacular Moroccan food in Paris while I was working there. 

Ambience: a bit cold for the evening. The door doesn't close properly and can get cold here even during a night in May. 

FOOD:
Most of the dishes are not quite right in flavor. The eggplant appetizer and sautéed okra side lack vibrant flavors - was quite bland. Not sure if they source the best quality veggies here. The lamb targine was pretty tender but the dish was super oily and the artichoke is a bit sour. 

I miss the perfectly cooked tagines at 404 in Paris (one must visit this place if you find yourself there).
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Having had tagine at least once a day for 10 days in a Morrocan vacation 3 months ago, I was finally ready and excited to have it again. Khamsa has been on my bookmarked list for a while and looked cosy for a date on a rainy evening.

I made a reservation on Yelp and I'm glad I did that because the place is quite tiny. We got seated right away and got the Califlower starter and the fish tagine.

Both these dishes were too bland and lacked enough flavor. It didn't remind us about the food in Morroco. It was also really expensive!

The service was okay was okay. The only thing that was really good was the presentation!
author: Divya S.

description:
Well-seasoned food, great service, intimate ambience. 

I got the lamb dish and it was A1. They cooked the lamb in a pot and poured it onto my plate upon serving. It had a few piquant pieces of salted some-type-of-citrus skin that was so soft and added a nice tanginess. There were olives and a clove of garlic which offered a different set of flavors. The lamb was amazing, the fat melted in my mouth, the meat fell apart easily and was juicy, tender, flavorful, and well seasoned. The veggies on the side included some purple potato, brussel sprouts, potato, and asparagus. I was actually very full from the servings--they gave me a lot more meat than I thought I could finish. 

The sweet potato chunks (appetizers?) were overly sweet so wasn't a huge fan of that.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Wow five star place. Great ambience- it's dark and quiet. Not too many tables inside so noise level is low. They have some tables outside too and a fireplace. 

He food was quite tasty. We got the duck, fish and chicken tagine. It was nice and juice. 
Service was great. Dinner was Not inexpensive.
author: Arjan N.

description: This was my first time eating Moroccan food and if my rating were only based on what we ate Khamsa would surely receive five stars! I tried the duck tagine (wonderfully tender and flavorful) and tangia (the slow roasted lamb could be cut with a fork and was paired with delicious roasted veggies). Both of which I would order again if I decide to return. After an hour at our table, while we were still finishing up drinks, our waiter asked us to leave because they had another reservation. We had arrived at 7:30 and were asked to leave to make room for an 8:45 reservation, but after spending $200 on a meal I was disturbed to dismissed to accommodate their desired fast turnover. I likely won't be returning because of it!
author: Rachael G.

description:
Yum yum yum. 

We walked in one evening and even though the tables were all full, there were still bar seats available. I love the spices that are used in Moroccan food and it's always served so beautifully.

We started with the chicken basteeya. I'd give that 4*; its not as good as the duck version at Mourad.

For our entrees, we shared the beef tagine and a lamb dish. Both were great but I think the beef had a slight edge. 

Each bite was full of flavor and kept me on my toes. I love it!
author: Yi Z.

description:
Dinner party for 5 on a Friday night at 6:30pm
Overall everyone enjoyed it and would not hesitate to come back!

FOOD
-Zaalouk- the puréed eggplant was tasty and the bread that it came will was nice and fluffy. Hrmmm perfect cold appetizer to start the meal with
-Kafta- lamb meatballs were cooked perfectly and seasoned well, satisfied my tomato sauce craving
-Chiflor- if I had to choose one least favorite dish, this would be the one. It was not bad, but I thought the cauliflower was a bit to cooked and I didn't care for so much creme fraiche on it. Would have preferred the creme fraiche on the side.
-Tangia- slow cooked lamb was very good and the other ingredients on the plate complemented well. 
-Chicken tagine- recommended by our waiter and it was tasty as well. The chicken was very tender though portions were a bit smaller
-Beef tagine- wanted to try it since many Yelpers wrote about it. I didn't think it was bland like some Yelpers said, but the flavors were certainly lighter. I thought the lighter flavor actually helped balance out the other stronger flavors of other dishes
-Couscous- good/solid
-Saffron rice with raisins- or what we heard the waiter say "side of fries". Hahaha my friend was so disappointed when we tried ordering fries but the waiter said he said "saffron rice". LOL. I loved the rice though. It was cooked perfectly and so yummy. 
-Baklava- good, but I've had better! Thought it was too wet and a bit too sweet
-Special phyllo dough cheese dessert- I'm not a cheese lover, but this was delightful. Very light and not too sweet at all. I think everyone liked this dessert more than the baklava because we kinda neglected the baklava after we had a taste of this one (we all shared desserts... and every dish)

AMBIANCE/DECOR
Restaurant is small and cozy. Nicely light with natural light from windows. Noise level surprisingly on the quiet side given how small the restaurant is. Just be watchful when walking through tables to get to your seat/restroom or leaving the restaurant. There is a small counter/bar area where you can enjoy a drink while waiting for a table. I'd say it's a good spot for date night, casual but could be a bit romantic/intimate too since it's cozy.  

SERVICE
Great and timely service. Waiter was friendly and gave us some good recommendations on what and how much to order. Food came out at a good pace and water cups were never left empty. Andes chocolate mints came with the bill.
author: Iris H.

description: Absolutely fell in love with this place! The vibe goes hand-in-hand with delicious items on the menu, amazing decor, and an excellent customer service. Don't miss on the chance to try the main with the lamb - it highlighted our evening. Beer & wine list includes handcrafted and exotic items from Morocco and other countries. Highly recommend this place!
author: Zhamal Z.

description:
This place is small, a bit packed for my taste, they maximized every inch of space to fit in people.  The service was not really interested in their job, just bringing and taking away dishes. 

The food:
the Khasma salad: it was not really chopped into pieces fit for consumption, the leaves were huge, whole dates, chunks of walnuts, I didn't like the presentation, the taste was nothing special either.
The chicken bastilla: while nicely presented was dry and the flaky pastry was hard and not flaky.
The couscous lamb: nice flavor, lost of lamb, but also a chunk of fat that should have never been there. The vegetables were all huge, again I like a more delicate presentation, perhaps they wanted to be rustic but didn't quite hit the mark.  

This place has potential but the service and food needs to up the game.
author: Inga W.

description:
Yesterday, I was at an offsite meeting. An hour in, I started daydreaming (don't front, you know you do it too!). 

Just when we were getting to the juicy NSFW stuff, I was startled by the loud crinkling of bags next to me. I looked to my left and the lady next to me was going to town on her monstrous super burrito. I sat there simultaneously side-eyeing and salivating each bite of stretchy cheese action as crema and salsa roja cascaded down the sides of the tortilla. 

Why you gotta be so cruel?! 

But, I suppose this wasn't as bad as when our former director thought it would be OK to bring in a whole rack of ribs for her lunch during a meeting. While talking, she would suck on the bones like....NVM. Keeping it classy! 

As soon as the meeting was over, I was hangry and on the hunt for a lunch spot. Khamsa, a new Moroccon Fusion restaurant popped up as one of my nearest bookmarks so I made my way there. 

Khamsa is located at the ground level of a luxury condo in a part of The Mission that doesn't get much foot traffic. Most businesses in the area are auto body shops so it was a nice change of scenery to walk into such a cute restaurant. While small, the owner(s) did a great job with making the space warm and inviting. There's also an outdoor patio for those rare warm days. 

When I walked in, there was no one in the dining room so I stood awkwardly near the bar area. After several minutes, I was able to get the attention of someone in the kitchen who sat me down. He said, he would bring me a menu but never did. Five minutes later, the host/server appears and brings me a menu to peruse. 

The Morrocon Fusion menu offers apps (e.g. basteeya), salads, and entrees (e.g. tagine). The lunch and dinner menu appear to have the same items but the prices are lower for lunch. Beer and wine only. 

I ordered the Beef Tagine with a side of rice. I was told the Beef Tagine comes with a side of salad or couscous so I went with the former which I don't recommend. More on that later. 

About 30 minutes later, my Beef Tagine w/ side salad ($17) arrives: http://bit.ly/2isCpug. There seems to have been a miscommunication and I didn't initially receive a side of rice ($5) as ordered. But, the server later brought it comped which I really appreciated: http://bit.ly/2w7VXra.

Sadly, the Beef Tagine was disappointing. While the English cut short ribs were meaty and tender, they were severely underseasoned/underspiced and there were too many sweet components making the dish cloyingly sweet: http://bit.ly/2w7IAXZ. It desperately needed an acid to cut the sweetness from the caramelized orange (tasted like candy), and the dates and honey balsamic dressing from the salad. I would skip the salad and order the couscous to help balance the sweetness from the short ribs.

Service was cordial but spotty even when it was empty. Water glass wasn't refilled until I was getting ready to leave and I had to go to the bar and ask the server for a box and the bill. Maybe it's because I went during lunch but the staff seemed to be distracted with delivery (?) people coming in and out. I'm sure dinner service may be better.

Khamsa is only a month young so I would give them several months to work out the kinks in the kitchen. Wishing them much success!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I have to admit I was a bit skeptical about this brand new spot in a brand new building at 15th and South Van Ness. The description on their website made it sound like one of those hipster-focused fusion restaurants where the owners intentionally neuter the flavors and spices of their native dishes to appease the masses. In fact, the more impatient food bloggers angling to become local taste makers are already referring to the restaurant as serving Moroccan-Californian fusion cuisine. That's not why I came here after work last week. I was just looking for a different take on vegetarian dishes since I'm eating wisely these days.

It's a compact spot with tables already occupied at 6PM, so I took a seat at the far left of the counter in order not to disrupt bigger parties coming in to try the place. The friendly server saw me struggle with my starter between the $11 Zaalouk and the $12 Chiflor, which was a small plate of charred cauliflower sprinkled with zaatar, a Middle Eastern blend of various herbs, crushed sesame seeds, and salt. It came with small dollops of crème fraîche mixed with Argon oil sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2vQC9Ke). It was delicious healthy eating with just a hint of decadence with the cream. For my entree, I bypassed the lamb, fish and beef to try the $18 Vegetarian Tajine.

The dish indeed came in a traditional tajine, a small one suitable for a solo diner. It was quite flavorful and fragrant with figs, raisins, almonds, summer squash, carrots, potatoes, and a lemon yogurt sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2vQC754). It automatically came with a side of Couscous to sop up all the goodness of the tajine (photo: http://bit.ly/2v5cTNA). I was already full when the server came by with a complimentary Zaalouk with pureed eggplant mixed with onions and tomatoes. It came with wedges of fresh pita that were hard to resist even though I had been avoiding carbs for weeks (photo: http://bit.ly/2vgmmko). Really delicious and quite filling, all of it. I will definitely come back with Jamie W.

FOOD - 4 stars...terrific vegetarian takes on classic Moroccan cuisine
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...modern space, a bit crowded but with the added bonus of patio seating
SERVICE - 5 stars...obviously I like a server who gives me extra food
TOTAL - 4 stars...too soon to award it five but a few more dishes may convince me they are delivering at that level
author: Ed U.

description:
I enjoyed their food. Portion size was decent. 

Packed full of flavor in every dish. 

The bastilla is a must try. Savory and hint of sweetness. Stuffed calamari has a different twist which was enjoyable. 

I recommend giving khamsa a try. Expect $50-60 per person.
author: Lyman C.

description: This is an upscale moroccan fine dining establishment in a not so great neighborhood. The restaurant is small in size but has a warm, inviting and modern ambiance. The service was fantastic. The presentation of the food is beautiful and the serving sizes make for a satisfying meal but you won't be stuffed to the brim. I ordered the vegetarian tagine which was exquisite in flavor. I wasn't crazy about the house dressing on the Mediterranean salad, it was too sweet for my taste. Everyone in my party was satisfied with their meal. It is a solid place that has vegetarian options and is gluten friendly. You should check it out!
author: Marta M.

description: Ambiance was great. A little tight so I wouldn't recommend a large party. Food was great very flavorful. 3 people shared the lamb, beef, egg plant (it's cold I wonder if it would taste better warm), Cauliflower (a little under cooked) and beers.
author: Justin I.

description:
4+ for the food , the service I'd probably give a 2 or 3. started off on an frustrating note as we were quoted an 40 min wait which we didn't mind . We waited out for the first 15 or so mins then as it was pretty cold outside we decided we'd get a drink at their bar. The host told us that wasn't possible. We couldn't take a space at the bar and wait for table so we had to pick one or the other, weird bc there were plenty of seats at the bar but okay fine. We then proceeded to wait over an hour and fifteen minutes with very little update from the host. But whatever it's SF , it's busy, it happens. Once we sat down we were starving and waiting to order!

We started with the BATATA HIEWA and Basteeya, both were pretty good. I enjoyed the basteeya more , the batata heiwa is good if you love sweet potato . For dinner I got the vegetable Tagine which I loved and my friend got the chicken kebabs. 

The interesting part was that we put in our main dish orders then ended up getting our check before it came out, we were so confused !! Turned out the server had dropped our ticket for the mains and also forgot we ordered them...off. So we did wait quite some time to get it. Thank god for the apps! The server was very nice about it so it wasnt too bad! 

I'd def come back but hopefully there's a different person at the front .
author: Hetal P.

description:
Wow I actually love this place! I've been here three times now, and have never been disappointed.

My favorite dish is the lamb couscous. The meat is soft and tender and full in flavor. I also like the beef tagine. The portion sizes are great - I can typically split it into two meals but I would still recommend ordering your own dish. 

I also like to order the Kanafeh, which is this cheese pastry soaked in sweet syrup with crushed pistachios sprinkled on top!

For those complaining about the prices, it's cheaper to come during lunch. (lunch menu prices are cheaper but I think the same portion size)

Bottom line? The food is comparable and authentic to the food I've tried in Morocco. Service is excellent and attentive. 

P.S. I think it's a good place to have date night too :)
author: Alicia L.

description: Great ambience with a nice outdoor seating and good food. This is the first time I tried Moroccan so I don't have anything to compare it against. The chicken tagine was delicious. The meat was perfectly cooked and seasoned. The lamb tanjia was good too but not as flavorful as the chicken. It was tender and cooked well. The sweet potato side dish was my favorite. Not a lot of vegetarian options though. I think there were maybe  3 vegetarian appetizers and only 1 entree in the menu. A bit pricey, but the portion sizes are large.
author: Lasya B.

description: Great for groups! The interior is a deep blue color that reminds me of the city of Essaouira in Morocco. Try the fish tagine and okra with pita bread for your meal and Knafeh for dessert.
author: Meryam B.

description:
Lovely interior decorations in this tiny spot, and there's even a covered outdoor patio! 

The service was also attentive and friendly. 

I got a few items: the khamsa salad, side of sauted veggies, and saffron rice to try a few things. Unfortunately none of my items really rocked my boat. The salad was drenched in the dressing so the leaves were all soggy..meh. 

I might come again to try the veg tangine. 

The most surprising part, was that this place is quite pricey..all entrees in the $20s.
author: Aria S.

description:
Awesome Moroccan food!
I am Moroccan myself and this really reminds me of my home, Khamsa will see me again soon!
author: Karim C.

description:
I have been looking for a Moroccan restaurant near my hood and glad to find Khamsa.  We were seated immediately and only two other tables were occupied. 

The waitress made suggestions on what to try; finally we ended up going with zaalouk, basteeya for appetizers and lamb Tanjia, and veggie tangie with couscous and saffron rice for the entree. 

They brought zaalouk first and 15 mins pass by -- they forgot the Basteeya, we then waited for someone to show up so we could remind them, but we got the entrees. The lamb was well cooked and the couscous was done great, but the veggie tangie was left with nuts tossed as an after thought -- my experience was roasted nuts having tangie, but that wasn't the case. The saffron rice was not warm enough. Wanted to love this place so much, but the food and service were only deserving a '3'.
author: Ram A.

description:
I've never been to Morocco so I LOVED my visit to Khamsa. We ordered the eggplant appetizer, the veggie tagine with the saffron rice and the dessert (can't remember the name but it had filo, sweet cheese, pistachios and a sweet syrup--and it was AMAZING!). Unlike some of the other reviewers, I thought these dishes were bursting with flavor! 

The eggplant was absolutely yummy and I loved that you could really taste the flavors of each of the ingredients... the eggplant wasn't drowned in the other ingredients like it can often be. The veggie tagine was perfectly cooked with a pleasant crunch from the almonds, the comfort of the potatoes and the bite of the carrots, it all worked really well for me. 

The decor was my favorite part! It's a departure from the kitschy Moroccan restaurants of the past. The decor is modern Moroccan that doesn't feel like it's trying too hard. 

The service needs work though. From what I could tell, there was only one waitress for the whole restaurant and the other waitress was being paid to be on her phone behind the counter. It was hilarious  to try to flag her attention. It was like she was confused that we wanted her help.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I actually wept a little because the delicious food simply prepared was so wonderful. 

 went with friends who I haven't seen for some time since they've moved to SF from West Oakland and the theme to enjoy catching up with them was front of mind, moreso even than the restaurant.  After providing several choices to choose from, I picked Khamsa, having seen their primary menu was Moroccan and I just love spicy and Mediterranean food.  

We had the most popular of the dishes (Zaaloouk, Kafta; Calamari (was spicy and great to me though too spicy for my friends).  

Khamsa salad was wonderful.  All of the flavors you want in medi food. 

Mains were Tangine (seafood, veggie and  beef ordered by friends) and we shared couscous and rice  and there was plenty for the 4 or us.  Well prepared sides and while I thought about the collard greens and sweet potatoes, I decided I'd be back anyway so it's fine to leave something for next time.  

I had the Tanjia since my feeling is medi=lamb and that's the tell of a great restaurant that knows how to cook.  That dish was so much food and so delicious, I took my leftovers home even after my friends tried the dish.  Big tender pieces of grilled lamb thoughtfully prepared by loving hands.  The servers were warm and friendly.  

Too much food and we passed on dessert.  

I can't tell you how much fun we had. 

Just a terrific choice.  Plan on bragging to make sure folks go here.
author: Carol W.

description:
In one word: mediocre.

Food was decent.  Lamb was well seasoned, and there was a lot of it.  The other dishes were okay.  Not bad, nothing that would make me come back again.  However, the dressing on the salad was sickeningly sweet.

The service was pretty laughable.  We were the only people in the restaurant, and twice I had to walk over to where the two waitresses were behind the bar to get any service, as they were both preoccupied with their phones.  

It would be funnier, except it was quite an expensive meal.  Safe to say I will never eat here again.  It's possible they were having an off night, but I kinda doubt it.
author: Micah D.

description:
Lively atmosphere and friendly service.  We had:
- Calamari (4/5) - Really delicious sauce with a great spicy kick.
- Mrouzia (3/5) - Massive lamb shank, but the flavor was pretty muted.
- Duck tajine - My girlfriend really enjoyed this, but I didn't try enough to have an opinion.
- Baclava (3/5)
author: Simon L.

description:
They still have a lot of work to do to get this place on par with the great restaurants of SF. I'm confused by the current 4.5 star average rating, as the food and service were both less than we expected on a Friday night.

We arrived on time for our reservation and while the table was ready, we were not seated for 30 minutes. 

The wine list is VERY limited. The malbec was quite bad and we switched to the cabernet. 

The basteeya was delicious and the only thing we really enjoyed, also the presentation was quite nice, we would order it again. 

The slow-cooked lamb was VERY DRY... doesn't that defeat the purpose of slow cooking? The flavors of this signature dish were too subtle, the whole thing lacked flavor. We shared this and didn't even finish it, which is surprising because we love lamb! This also needs some kind of side, unfortunately we ordered the couscous, which was equally flavorless. It was nice and fluffy, but so bland, and did not complement the very bland/dry dish we ordered it with.

While we wanted to try the kunefe, they only had baklava left, so we opted out, because our meal was so disappointing. 

I really want to give them a higher rating because the staff are really kind and the ambience is beautiful, but the food was just so disappointing. I would try this place again on a less busy night, to see if other dishes are better.
author: Kimia M.

description: The restaurant is small and cute but the food we ordered wasn't flavorful. The vegetable tagine was too bland for me. I had to ask for salt. The salad my friend ordered wasn't that great either.
author: Shivani S.

description:
I went a few weeks ago with a few girlfriends. The food was really tasty and the space beautiful--except maybe for the really creepy mural of a blue-faced lady.  I will be going back for sure!!

Food
App- Basteeya, so unique and definitely should try. It's a sweet and savory pastry with chicken, almonds, cinnamon and powdered sugar but somehow it all works. I think it was slightly on the dry-side but I would order it again. 

Side- Chiflor, if you love cauliflower get this dish. 


Main-Beef Tagine- amazing! super soft and moist beef. Would definitely recommend. The portion is good and 2 people can share of ordering sides. 

My friends ordered dessert but I did not try it. However they really liked the baklava and ice cream!
author: Maliha Z.

description: Best Moroccan food that we've found in the city and very reasonably priced. Extremely authentic -- it reminds us of our meals in Morocco!
author: Ish H.

description: space is tiny but the food is good, I love the tea so much, especially the decoration is soo beautiful. Make a reservation before you go always is the best option.
author: Faye L.

description: Incredible food, service and ambience. Amazing Tanjia, and surprisingly, baklava!
author: Jordan R.

description: The portions are ridiculously small. The bastilla is a huge theft - it costs you $18 for only 1 very DRY bastilla - like the rice. We've waited half an hour for the appetizer. Really NOT WORTH the money you put
author: Marie S.

description:
Noticed that this place had opened up in the neighborhood last week. I'm not normally super adventurous with my culinary exploits but was lured in due to the super chic ambience. My date and I opted for the Malfouf (super zesty chicken eggplant appetizer), Khamsa salad, & Beef tagine with a side of couscous. All the dishes had the perfect balance of being incredibly tasty / flavorful while not making you feel super stuffed, this must be the Californian culinary twist!!! I think this is the perfect place to take a date to experience an exotic cuisine & still be able to go out. 

Long & short, I will be back!!
author: Harman B.

description:
Took my husband here for his birthday dinner and was excited to try based off the yelp reviews. Now I'm regretting ever making that decision. Decor, ambiance is great but the food was horrible, flavorless and expensive. I don't mind an expensive meal, but if its worth it. Lamb dish that we shared was $30, dry and veggies were hard and bland. Portion size of the okra and eggplant dishes were tiny and the rice dish I ordered was crunchy.

I have had authentic Moroccan food many times so maybe ill just stick to that rather than this modernized version.
author: Inas A.

description:
Aaaargh I wanted so badly to love this place!!

On the bright side, our waiter was really sweet and attentive, have no complaints there. He also made the great recommendation of getting the lamb shank that we really enjoyed as one of our mains.

The not so great:

The eggplant appetizer was disappointing. Loved the smokiness but it was stringy and the addition of tomatoes resulted in way too much acid. I would suggest more creaminess and no tomato. 

The lamb shank was very tasty as mentioned. Would be nice if it came with some couscous or rice as keep in mind it was steep at $30. The side of  vegetables were sadly not a great consolation prize as they were soggy and under seasoned that cane with our other main.

Lastly we got some dessert that came with ice cream that I have to advise against. The pastry component was cold (we were told that it was intentional) but it tasted very stale. Especially with a cold side of ice cream, I recommend it to be hot.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Traveling to Morocco in a few weeks so decided to give Moroccan food a go!

The Vegetarian Tagine was delicious- there was such a unique blend of ingredients that I would've never thrown together myself (almonds, raisins, yams, olives, to name a few). We also got the lamb with couscous and a side of sweet potatoes and yams which were good as well. I felt full at the end, but not gross and greasy.

I tried the Moroccan mint tea as well as a Moroccan red wine blend. I would recommend trying both because why not?

What made the dinner especially enjoyable was all the finishing touches - the decor made me feel like I was in a different city. I loved everything from the tile on the counter, to the chairs, to the tea pots, hanging wall rug and the clay pots. It's a great date night or group dinner place.

Next time I would love to sit out on the patio!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Delight food and great service. A great place for vegan options as well.
author: Chen C.

description: Food was presented really well and tasted decent.  Not a big fan of Moroccan food but this place exceeded my expectations. Generally I feel it is overpriced and overhyped -- there are much better restaurant that are worth the $$$ in Mission Area.
author: Zeba K.

description: Cute little spot. Great service. The food was on point for sure. This wasn't planned, but ended up being a good call. I believe I got the Chicken Tagine, and it was very well done.
author: Jonah K.

description: I did not have any entres, only appetizers - Eggplant and grilled calamari. They were both very good. The place is nicely decorated and service quick and friendly. A bit of a tight space. My friend didn't like her chicken kebab she said it lacked flavor but I am going to let her speak for herself in her own review.
author: Xiu L.

description:
Delicious new restaurant in the mission with great Tagines, desserts, and wine. The atmosphere is intimate with high ceilings and warmth created by both the ovens and the diners. We had the beef tagine, lamb couscous, and chicken kebabs when we went. This is a perfect combo, as you can use the couscous to soak up the extra juices from the tagine. The beef tagine has some of the softest beef I've ever tasted in my life. It falls off your fork and into your mouth. 

Highly recommend as a date spot and for groups of 4-6.
author: Sam P.

description:
This is a very small place, but because of the high ceiling and nice decor, it did not feel small at all.  I came here for lunch with 3 other people. The staff are very nice and friendly. The food took a little too long to be served and I was originally starting to get annoyed but when I tried my Fish Tagine when it finally arrive, it was so delicious that I overlooked the fact that it took so long.  The fish was so full of flavor. I loved it and would definitely recommend this dish. I will come back for sure and order the same thing.

Update 3 weeks later:  Sure enough, I came back and had the fish again and it was just as good the second time around, and this time the service was perfect.  We did not wait long for our food at all.
author: P G.

description:
I was really excited to come here, was meeting friends and family after a long time apart.  Saw the great yelp reviews.   There were 6 of us.  Khamsa is a really cutr restaurant, nice decor and feel.   Very hip.   But the food and service were subpar.  They recommended the cauliflower appetizer, which was a dud.   And the chicken in pastry appetizer, which was average.  I've had much better.  She also recommended the tagines.  

The chicken tagine was ok.  Not amazing by any means.  The lamb couscous was tasteless.  The veggie tagine was a weird flavor and almost unedible.  I've had moroccan multiple times in the past.  
The service was horrendous.  Took a long time to be seated even with reservations and an empty table.  When they gave us the check, the lady looked at her watch.  They kept giving us the evil eye when we chatted during dessert.  It seems since we were already committed to a 20% tip since we were a party of 6, it didnt matter how they treated us.  

Oh, and it was super expensive.  My pocketbook is feeling the pain since I treated.  small entrees were in the $20's and $30's.  A few sprigs of cauliflower was $12. 

I wouldnt come back here.
author: Monica L.

description: I can't believe I didn't know a place this good so close to where I live! If you like succulent, fall off the bone meat, this is the place for you! Liked the duck the best out of the lamb, chicken, and duck entree which surprised me as I though I'd like the lamb the best.
author: Gabs M.

description:
Nestled in one of the "shady" neighborhood's this place is a hidden surprise. 
I liked the ambiance and the food was great. Their seating place is limited, so I would not encourage a big group. We were a party of 7 on a light night, so it was not a problem for us. They have outdoor seating as well, I would want to be back on a warm day make use of that. 

Special mention to the Moroccan tea. It was great.
author: Milana R.

description: Love the intimate tight hidden space.  The food was delicious and the menu was small so I'm pretty sure everything is good here.  Got the duck tangine, Goat Tanjia and that sweet ass saffron honey lamb.  All three were good but next time I would throw in a veggie dish to balance out the meat trio.  This place was ALMOST perfect except for one thing....the cauliflower that's even more ridiculous than a $10 avacado toast.  This was a 4 piece $12 dollar, roasted maybe steamed, maybe who the hell cares it was only 4 PIECES! I guess the saying is true...only in SF where you can pull this shit off and everyone would think its normal.
author: Vince L.

description: Everything about this restaurant was great. I took a friend here for his birthday. Everything was on point from customer service, to ambiance, the tenderness of the lamb tagine, the flavorful okra, and smooth white wine the waiter recommended. They even threw in a free baklava and ice cream when they learned we were celebrating. This place is well worth the drive from Oakland and I would definitely recommend it.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
Came here on a rainy wednesday. We booked a table on opentable but there was no wait at 540pm. as we left close to 7pm, the place was still quiet. I'm guessing it's either the bad weather or people didn't want to head out on hump day.
We did some research here before coming and the cousin discovered that they upped their prices. When we got there, we realized they upped their prices AGAIN. But we gave them a fair chance.
We got the kafta and the meatballs were good. They were moist in the center and outside was a little soft. The seasoning was done perfectly. Nothing was too salty.
The chicken tagine was amazing. The meat was falling off the bone. Cousin and I felt like they must have marinated the meat for a looong time. Again, the seasoning wasn't overwhelming. It wasn't overly salty. The potatoes were soft but seasoned well as well.
The lamb couscous was great. The lamb was not too game-y. It was also very tender and soft. you really could just use your fork to break apart the meat. the couscous was cooked perfectly and the vegetables were great. the only thing was the sweet potato was a little too sweet for us.
The Moroccan lemonade was delicious as well. But for $6 a glass, it is a little steep. 
Overall, we left with our bellies full. Definitely would come back again. Just hopefully they hold off on raising their prices for a couple more years.
author: Jessica H.

description: What a great place. We have been there yesterday for the first time me. We had the lamb, beef and duck dish as well as some peeled peppers. Everything was delicious, and I felt like in Marrakesh. Try out the wines from Lebanon - dry and crisp and different from your daily Napa white or red. Our waiter had a warm and welcoming personality and was competent too . Can't wait to come back!!!
author: David F.

description:
A refreshing addition to SF's culinary scene.

My friends and I ordered the calamari, meatballs, chicken kebab, slow cooked lamb, lamb couscous and a chilled bottle of French rose. Very tasty and surpassed all expectations. The ambience was great and the service was excellent. 

The interior felt like you were sitting inside a Moroccan jewelry box. Perfect place for a date.

This one is a keeper on the repeat visit list.
author: Desmond F.

description:
Amazing restaurant! Came here on a whim once I found it on yelp and had to go here. We ordered the kafta, saffron with rice, chiflor(?) and one more thing that I forgot lol. Woops. Everything was amazingly seasoned. The vibe and decorations were very Moroccan esque and the waiter was very friendly! 
Side note- being as I traveled to Morocco in August I was biased as nothing beats eating the real deal food in its own country( which was some of the best food I've ever ate) I was skeptical, but this place is amazing. I can't wait to come back and take a step back into Morocco!
author: Nessa H.

description: WOW!!!  This Legit Moroccan restaurant was amazing.... It tasted like I was with my Aunt in Asilah trying tagine for the first time.  Really it was so so good.  The Harira soup, Basteeya, and lamb Tangia were ALL AMAZING.  Authentic.  I conveyed my compliments to the chef who is incredibly talented.  The decor was gorgeous and very classy.  The staff was very professional, friendly and attentive but gave us all the time in the world to order and enjoy.  I had an appointment nearby and yelped for dinner ideas earlier today and made this reservation.  I am so very glad I did and I will be back, I hope many many times.  Best Moroccan food I have had since I was vacationing there in 2013 and trust me I have been looking ever since.  This is the real deal.
author: Amber B.

description: The food here is complex, in a good way. Layered flavors, perfectly cooked meat, fresh warm mint tea. The ambience was really elegant, perfect for a date night out.
author: Erin W.

description: I went there for my friends birthday! Loved the place, design and atmosphere! The food was great and customer service by our waitress Gulba was outstanding! We've tried almost everything and I'd love to go back and have it all again and again! Highly highly recommend this place!
author: Maria O.

description:
This place was great. I had the tanjia and some appetizers and was able to try small parts of other mains people tried in our group. 

Everything was very tasty. We ate outdoors and everything was quite pleasant. 

One of the better places I've been to at a similar price point in SF. 

This would be a good place for a group of friends to hang out for dinner. It seems like it'd make a good date spot as well.
author: Jared R.

description: We had the basteeya, lamb couscous, and tanjia. The flavor combination of the basteeya was completely new to us (niether of had had Moroccan before), and we both enjoyed it immensely. The filo was buttery but light, and the filling was very unique as well. We both had portions way bigger than we expected and the restaurant was very generous with how much meat they gave us. Most of the goat pieces in the tanjia were nice and soft while others were a bit jerky-like. I'm not sure if that's how it's meant to be but I liked both types:P I tried a bit of my friend's lamb couscous and that was also very flavorful. I'd definitely love to come back to try the other dishes.
author: Risako O.

description:
Delicious and innovative food, great service and trendy atmosphere.
Highly recommended!

I give it 4 stars as since they've just opened they're still adjusting for demand, so a few dishes weren't available. Otherwise, all was perfect!
author: Pablo A.

description:
This place is very overpriced. I met up with a friend here (partially based on the pictures showing a nice ambience and menu with moderate prices). Restaurant is loud and echo-y. After my friend arrived and we took a look at the menu, we noticed that prices were more than 50% higher than the picture of the menu on Yelp had showed (aka EXPENSIVE). I guess if you make tech money that can be wasted on food that was a third cheaper not that long ago, then fine, but that's not me. We decamped for a cheaper (delicious) place elsewhere in the Mission. 

Also, the lighting in here sucks.
author: Jason H.

description:
1. Food: This place had good food, but was not as amazing as I had expected based on the other Yelp reviews. I'm a huge fan of Moroccan fare and have tried various iterations of the dishes they served, but was not blown away by the meal here though they weren't bad.

2. Ambiance: I was drawn to this place because of the outdoor seating, it's quite unique and cozy. However, I ended up sitting on the inside of the restaurant because we didn't have a reservation- what bothered me was that the outdoor seating was pretty empty the whole time we were there but we weren't welcome to it. The interior is nice as well, just a bit dark- probably better in a date setting! 

3. Buck value: It was expensive!! I was quite surprised at how expensive the meal was given that we didn't order very many things so that we could share. 

4. Service: Staff was friendly but definitely a bit confused- it was clear that they didn't have everything in order just yet. Getting their attention took a while and the service was slow overall.  

5. Extras: I do like this place, and would give it another shot. I think I was a little extra salty because I sat inside and not outside but the next visit is going to be on a more special day.
author: Spriha S.

description: I had an incredible lunch here the other day. We were the only people there! The salmon was perfectly cooked. It was a large portion and included delicious fresh vegetables and fluffy couscous. I can't wait to go back to try more!
author: Mark S.

description: Great food, unique atmosphere! Would recommend for date night or just hang out and have some good food. Lamb entree & Baklava were delish!!
author: Fiorella G.

description:
A great moment in this beautiful Moroccan bistrot, the food is between tradition and modernism, subtle and excellent.
Definitely recommend the Tanjia!!! Amazing!!!
And You can't miss the Kanafah in dessert!!!
author: Jean-pierre S.

description: Amaaaaaaaazing Moroccan food and the atmosphere is cozy and quaint. Highly recommend this place.
author: SD D.

description:
Wow! Blown away by Khamsa! 
When you first walk in you are suddenly transported to another world. The decor and vibe of the place is top notch. They have a beautiful painting on the wall that you notice right away after opening the door and colorful tile accenting the blue walls. You can definitely tell that they put a lot of thought into the look and feel of the space. They also make sure to keep mellow music playing, I'm pretty sure I heard bossa nova in the background which is one of my favorite genres. 
Now the food. 
I had high expectations from the first second we walked in because you can smell the food cooking, and everything smelled fresh. 
We started off with the zaalouk (puréed eggplant) and the Khamsa salad. Both were really good but I honestly can't remember ever having a better salad than this one in my life. 
There were a few of us so we ordered multiple entrees, 
I ordered the Tanjia (slow cooked lamb). I had asked the server what was the one dish I needed to get and this is what he recommended. He was definitely right. It was cooked perfectly and cut like butter with just the fork. 
We also ordered the beef tajine and chicken tajine. If I were to ever not order the Tanjia again I would most definitely order the beef tajine. It was falling right off the bone and I kept staring over to see if I could steel another taste. The chicken tajine was in line with everything we had eaten. Perfectly cooked, juicy, tender chicken.
Dessert
We had the kunafeh, and the server having remembered one of us was celiac brought a side of vanilla ice cream so she wouldn't feel left out. The kunafeh was a cheese pastry that was light and tasty. 
All in all, I am certain that I have found my new favorite restaurant!
author: andrew p.

description:
Only place I've seen with Moroccan wine. If you love food, come here... usually i only leave reviews when I'm mad. Trust me  : )

Love the vibe! Quiet, cozy, great decor. Good for people wanting a good glass of wine, and a chill night.
author: Bauble C.

description: Amazing new Moroccan restaurant in SF. Everything was great from the food to the ambiance. I had the Beef Tagine and the Khamsa salad. Highly recommend both! I love how it's a more modern take on traditional Moroccan food. I traveled to Morocco recently and the food is just as great. I'm very excited to come back and try other items on the menu!
author: Trish P.

description:
Look at other non 5-star reviews and notice a trend.
We made a reservation for 8pm, didn't sit down until 8:30. Tell me, what's the point of making a reservation just to wait 30 minutes for a table?

Wine was mediocre and overpriced.
$50 for a bottle for a place like this?

Lamb was tender and well-cooked but lacked any kind of real flavor, at least some salt would've helped greatly. 

Atmosphere was nice. 
Would not recommend.
author: Yevgeniy V.

description: I've been to Khamsa twice now and LOVE it. It's a small, quaint dining room but works well. The food is fantastic - I recommend the beef tagine, khamsa salad, and any of the desserts. Fantastic experience each time.
author: Min M.

description:
Just off the beaten gourmet path on 16th, this delightful Moroccan/Mediterranean restaurant is a gem we accidentally discovered with a group of our friends. And so glad we did!

- Traditional Moroccan food is on par with the highest standards.
- Portions are substantial.
- Menu is rather extended for a small (but spacious) place.
- Service is nothing short of perfect!

My wife's and my personal favorites were goat tajine, and duck tajine, basteeya and of course baklava!

Will definitely be coming back :-)
author: Gennady S.

description:
Food was good but not amazing...
Haven't had Moroccan food in SF so can't really compare but definitely had better elsewhere! 
Typical SF prices 
Service was excellent
author: P K.

description: Opened up so close to my place and can pop in whenever although it does get crowded. The Hariza soup is my favorite. They have a good wine selection and non-alcoholic beverages too. Decor is great. I recommend it for lunch and dinner. Outdoor seating is heated and nestled in a little area. Reservations may be needed but also worth the pop in if you are nearby.
author: Lauren A.

description:
So delicious! My friends and I ordered the fish tagine, the beef and couscous tagine, and the chicken kebabs. Everything was deliciously flavorful and memorable. The interior of the restaurant is cute and cozy, and they also have outdoor tables with heat lamps. The staff is very sweet and friendly, and had some great suggestions for our group for dinner.  We were indecisive about which wine we wanted to go with, so they were kind and attentive enough to give us all a tasting of the two we couldn't decide between. 

We also had the tanjia, and while it was good, I was a little thrown off by the fact that it was cold. Not sure if it was supposed to be served cold or if maybe we got an order that was sitting out for a while. Regardless, I'd highly recommend trying out this restaurant!
author: Sw A.

description:
We tried it per reviews.  Service and ambience and location are good. 

But the food was not tasty. We tried the cauliflower which felt like it was just boiled and served with sauce. 
The veggie entre was not tasty. 
Only tho g I liked was the eggplant in appetizer, which was served cold. 

The most important pita bread was not made in-house. It was a packet pita from grocery store and headed and served. 

For the prices it def was not worth it.
author: D D.

description: Some of the best food I have ever had.  The meat is cooked perfectly and melts in your mouth. The spices are perfectly balanced.  I love this place.
author: Peter L.

description: Having visited to Morocco, I've been looking for a low-key Moroccan place that's Bart accessible. This is it. Food was delicious - got the lamb couscous, fish tagline, and kale salad. Everything came quick and tasty. Also pretty good Moroccan lemonade and malbec :) really nice ambiance, great for a date night. There's outdoor seating too, with pretty flaming heaters. Anyway, check it out!
author: Lulu S.

description: Spectacular food, great environment, friendly staff! Not on a main thoroughfare, but a great gem. We got the lamb shank - perfectly falling off the bone. The zaalouk (eggplant) and chicken bastilla were great as well. And the kunefe dessert - a cheesy pastry recommended by the server, was incredible. I'll definitely be back!
author: Roxy W.

description: The ambiance is nice and service good. However, all the food was overcooked and bland except the carrot ginger soup. Had the cauliflower appetizer, beef tagine and lamb with couscous
author: Samson W.

description: Very good authentic Moroccan food. The kefta, couscous, zaalouk, tagine, bastilla, and mloukhia are very true to Moroccan cuisine standards and absolutely delicious. Moroccan cuisine is a beautiful medley of Indian flavors and French sophistication.
author: Youness B.

description:
Five stars and will absolutely be back. Went here based on a friend recommendation, as we love Moroccan food. 

Everything we ate was delicious. I highly recommend the chicken bastilla appetizer, as it is so perfectly seasoned. 

As main dishes, the table had two chicken tagine dishes, two mrouzia (lamb shank, sweetened with dates), and one Tanji (chunks of lamb). 

For dessert, they were out of kunafa, so we tried the baklava and Moroccan "cookies" which are nut filled fried and honey covered triangles. Amazing! Also be sure to order the Moroccan tea! Has a great hint of cardamom.

The spot is quite tiny so I would recommend a recommendation way ahead of time. Not ideal for large groups but we had 5 and it was great. The seating arrangement is long communal tables.
author: Antoinette C.

description: I walked by this place on a walk the other day and decided to give it a shot. Boy, this was a good decision. Everything about this place was cute [and I mean everything ;)]. Portions are small, but they fill you up and are delicious. And the service was good and the waiter was very attentive. Should have gotten his name #fail. Will definitely be returning again.
author: George O.

description:
I had an incredible lunch here
Definitely recommend the Tanjia
Amazing
And You can't miss the Kanafah in dessert. Best desert that i have eaten in a while
author: James M.

description:
Very good restaurant!!! We love  Mediterranean food specially Moroccan .
The food is so good and big portions , the service was so nice and fast !!
We loved it :)
author: Mary B.

description: The service was great and the food was amazing. The lamb was just perfect, best lamb I've tried for a while. I look forward to dining here again.
author: Josue G.

description: Great food great people great hospitality. I started coming here a few months ago for a glass of wine after work and I've had such a warm experience here that I kept coming back. The food has a very authentic taste and the restaurant has just the perfect vibe for a business meeting or a intimate date.
author: Travis S.

description: Food was very average. Goat was tough. Duck was dry and so was the chicken kebab. Appetizer was tasty.
author: Kora L.

description: A surprisingly good experience. It's easy to miss if you're not familiar with the area for its in the vicinity of Public Works which is a home for various musical events and shows. I must say ordering the Kafta (Lamb & Beef) meatballs were a solid choice. My girlfriend enjoyed the eggplant appetizer as well. If you're not to caught up on "gamey" dishes go for the Duck and or Goat dishes in my opinion. Lastly, it's a cozy establishment but it can get a little tight with seating...however with that said I will be back.
author: Ewell C.

description: Beautiful little spot. Ambiance is perfect for a date night. Food was delicious, service attentive.
author: Jessica L.

description: Tucked away in the mission, a great spot for Moroccan flavors. We loved the food and wine. Call ahead for a table as there might be limited seating on a busy day.
author: Anisha A.

description:
I had a dinner here recently sitting outside and had a fantastic experience. I ordered lamb and it was well cooked and juicy. The appetizers were delicious. One of my favorite parts is presentation of each dish and the ambience. This place has a good vibe for both casual evening or a romantic date. The owners seemed to put a lot of effort in creating the right atmosphere and details.

The service was impeccable. I will definitely be back.
author: Evgeni H.

description: Arrived with a party of 4 with a reservation on a cold night. Without telling us, they set our reservation outside on the patio. Unacceptable. We ended up walking around in the mission for a while in the cold looking for food before giving up and Ubering home to order delivery. We won't be back.
author: Garrett G.

description: We arrived in time for our reservation and discovered our table was given to someone else
author: Rohit D.

description: We had a lovely dinner here on a Saturday evening. The restaurant was busy but not too bustling. Food was flavorful - we got a goat dish and chicken tagine, as well as sides of couscous and batata hiewa (a sweet potato dish) - the sides were especially delicious and we enjoyed the sprinkling of raisins. The interior is charning and inviting and service was great. Would recommend.
author: Charmaine C.

description: This place is a little hidden gem. The food is delicious, satisfying, and comforting. The staff is friendly and politely. I recommend trying a tagine.
author: Tara T.

description: i really wanted to love khamsa, but to be honest, it was just okay. my gf is all into the hot n new, so for girls night, i chose khamsa since the reviews have been so good, and it's fairly new! easy access from 16th street BART as well, so that's always a plus. the restaurant is located on 15th, a few doors down from sixth course (which closed too early so we couldnt give it a try, so we will need to be back). i made a reservation for 3 for 7:30, but our table wasnt close to being ready, so we opted to sit at the bar. beer & wine only, and the wine is a little pricey. for sustenance, we ordered: basteeya, collard greens, chicken tagine, lamb tagine, and the couscous to sop it all up. they have a pretty small kitchen, and were catering to basically a full restaurant that evening, so our food came out on the slow side (despite them assuring us that service is fast).  i thought everything was just all right.. the collards were cold! which was disappointing. the meats were tender, but lacked depth of flavor that i usually associate with this style of cooking and cuisine. i thought the couscous side dish was nice, but there was a bit too much jam. there are only 2 desserts on the menu, so plan accordingly...
author: Christina L.

description: Phenomenal menu! Nice intimate spot. Took a group of 8 here so we were able to try everything on the menu family style. I'm not a huge fan of calamari but their appetizer and the sauce was amazing. The staff were all attentive and accommodating. Definitely going back and highly recommend! $75 per person with copious amounts of Moroccan wine.
author: Luke L.

description:
Great food! Veggie tagine was flavorful! be sure to order a side of couscous if you need some carb to go with your tagine. The lamb dish (not the tagine) was delicious as well. Lamb was done well /right consistency!
Fish tagine was really good, although little bit of salt would make the dish more flavorful!  Service was really  good! They don't yet have a regular dessert menu, we requested if they could make a dessert dish out of those delicious dates and honey that came with the lamb dish and they offered us a plate free of charge! that was a really nice gesture!  overall solid food. Little on the sweeter side, but thoroughly enjoyable!
author: Raja K.

description: I love everything about this place. The space is clean and inviting, and beautifully designed with Mediterranean tiles, lighting fixtures and colors. Every detail seems to be carefully considered, from the elegant tea service to the jewel box that carries your bill. There is also great music (my boyfriend describes it as "modern Arabic pop") playing. The service is attentive and the food is BEAUTIFUL AND DELICIOUS. We had the kofte, the lamb couscous and the basteeya. The flavors were delicately layered in each dish. The couscous had an almost buttery, nutty flavor and the lamb was tender and moist. I had the kofte on a Mediterranean salad that had a delicious, bright dressing, salty, almost bitter olives balanced by mild feta. We had to take the basteeya home untasted because we were so full, but the dish itself, like everything else we ate, was GORGEOUSLY presented. What a surprising gem of a find!
author: Susan C.

description: I found Khamsa thanks to yelp. It is an amazing place! The decoration is very unique, a perfect mix of tradition and modernity. The food is amazing, very tasty and flavorful, and the portion sizes are perfect. The team is amazing, very friendly. Also you should give a try to the Moroccan wines they have, it is pretty rare to find them in SF! Khamsa is one of these places that will become very trendy in the following months, so check it out now before it becomes insanely crowded!
author: Sophia E.

description: I think this place has people make up good yelp reviews. Prices are high, and food and service are mediocre. Don't waste your money.
author: Justin I.

description: Food is ordinary (for SF) and over-priced.  Dine there is you have more money that is good for you.
author: Dave G.

description:
Had a great, great meal with my wife and friends on Saturday evening (friends who are getting married in Marrakesh in about a month, so they know they're Moroccan food)! As it turns out, the very wine they were looking to source for the wedding can be enjoyed at Khamsa - this was a good initial indication.

From there, both the eggplant and cauliflower starters were delicious. Specifically, the eggplant was deep and smokey - I'm already thinking getting back for round 2 in the next week or so.

For the main, I went with the leg of lamb - it was falling off the bone flavorful. The raisin, squash, and onion base really combined well. Delicious. 

My wife, who's vegetarian, raved about the tagine (veggie). 

As for the decor and atmosphere: It's intimate yet exciting. The blue walls, indoor/outdoor space, and colorful Moroccan tile dance together really well.

Needless to say, we'll be back soon.
author: Ross C.

description: Really enjoyed my experience here. Fantastic to have a place like this open in our 'hood. Not many Moroccan restaurant in SF to my knowledge so good addition. Came here with small group. Everything was well prepared. Particularly liked the Basteeya and Lamb Couscous. Friends like there's as well but didn't try others. Also prices were on par or lower than most places of this caliber in city. Also really liked that is was classy joint but also still casual and homey. Good overall "vibe". Staff was great all around. Definitely be going back.
author: Adam Z.

description: Khamsa is a gem!  I spent almost a month traveling in Morocco, and Khamsa is the real deal.  They've thought of every detail down to the painted tiles, the candles, and the lanterns.  The salads were fresh and bright, and the braised lamb shank fell right off the bone.  Liza who runs the front of the house is a doll and will take good care of you. Definitely recommend taking a detour off Valencia Street to have a fabulous time at Khamsa.
author: Reality Check S.

description: Moroccan food at its best. Amazing experience from flavorful food to genuine friendly staff - authentic ambiance with a modern touch. Make sure to order as many konafas as people in your party: DELICIOUS and obviously not for share! Great new addition to SF culinary scene.
author: Lamiaâ B.

description: Great Morrocon food! I'd recommend the chicken basteeya, slow roasted lamb and kunafeh for dessert. The ambience and service was nice too, enjoy!
author: Anita S.

description: Every detail is attended to. The beef tagine, saffron rice and uniquely delicious appetizers were all filling and flavorful. There's both a wonderfully decorated indoor space with a great outdoor space. It was perfect for dinner with a group of friends with great prices.
author: Sarah T.

description: Very classy. Very yummy. Very authentic. Amazing food quality and presentation. Highly recommended.
author: Aditya S.

description: We tried Khamsa on a Tuesday evening. The food and the service were great. My husband's lamb dish was even served in a Tagine! This place does a great job of putting a modern spin on traditional Moroccan food.
author: Marvin V.

description: Everything we had was excellent. Great new addition to the neighborhood. Cauliflower was fantastic.
author: Bill R.

description: I work close by so I was anxiously awaiting the opening of this restaurant and my first meal there did not disappoint! I got the chicken sandwich and Moroccan lemonade and they were both great. Too pricey to be a daily lunch go to, but I'd say their prices are typical for a nice dinner in SF. Definitely recommend trying this new spot!
author: Meghan N.

description: I had high hopes for this place. I love Moroccan food, but the food was so dry and bland. Little over priced for what we got. The waiter keep bring food without clearing the table, which was a little awkward because we had to hold the dirty plates up so they can put the new dishes down and handing them the dishes. Needs some improvements, big time.
author: Ree G.

description: I was not impressed, to be honest. I ordered the mrouzia, which looked great in a picture on Yelp. But the meat was severely overcooked, to the extent that lamb, which should melt in the mouth tasted dry and chalky. They were gracious enough to replace it with the saffron chicken dish, which was better than the lamb, but still quite mediocre. At that price point, there is another middle eastern restaurant called tuba, that would knock your socks off. Compared to that, Khamsa has much to learn.
author: Shashank C.

description: Nice food, giving much needed bump to the Middle Eastern / Mediterranean  options in the Mission. Very good service as well, they seated us without a reservation despite being packed. Cozy vibes inside and outdoor seating option too. All in all a good addition to the neighborhood gets Khamsa arba'ah stars from me.
author: Arzan R.

description: Had an outstanding meal! The service is "slow" but I found it a really nice way to have a leisurely meal. We asked the waitress to recommend a meal and it came out perfectly. Highly recommended!
author: David E.

description:
I went with several friends. They all thought it was pretty good - I thought it was mediocre. If I personally had to rate it, I'd give it 3 stars but since I was the odd one out I'm giving it 4.

While the service, atmosphere and prices were all great, the food was mediocre. We had the beef tagine, tanjia, veg tagine, the khamsa salad, and a side of couscous. I felt that the lamb was very dry. The dishes all lacked flavor, despite being cooked well. Nothing I had was particularly satisfying. The order came out to around $35/pp, which felt reasonable given the amount of food we got. In the future, I think I'll just pay twice as much and go to Mourad for some of the best Moroccan I've ever had.
author: Tim M.

description: What a wonderful find this place is! Had a lovely late lunch here in this calm, clean, comfortable space. Food was delicious, service gracious. Look forward to revisiting sometime soon, and definitely recommend discovering this place for yourself, particularly if you enjoy authentic Moroccan food at decent prices.
author: Cathryn B.

description: Really nice restaurant with yummy middle eastern food. They also have outdoor seating. Nice cozy neighborhood or date place.
author: K C.

description: Food was good, service was excellent. Had a great meal there. Portions could be bigger. The lamb and beef melt in your mouth. A very unique dining experience. Well worth it.
author: John E.

description: Really cute place, the experience was great and the food was great. The Khamsa salad was delicious and the kefta was too. Meat was really well spiced and the rice was so good. Worth it!
author: Aya O.

description: The place decorated nicely and service is professional but that's about it. Everything we ordered was poorly executed, food was either missing spices or was overly spiced with some condiment. Beef tagine wasn't tender, and so was the calamari, rice was dry, couscous was terrible... what can I say - avoid.
author: Tamir A.

description: Managed to snag a table for four on a busy Friday night. Everyone liked what we had. The smoky eggplant spread and the duck were outstanding. Recommended.
author: Don S.

description: This is an upscale yet overpriced restaurant. The tables for two are too close to each other. The food is inconsistent. We had the calamari as an appetizer and it was tough and overcomes although the sauce was delicious. The chicken tagine was delish but the chicken kebab was dry and not very flavorful. The prices are way too High for what you get. We won't be back.
author: John S.

description: We went when they first opened, and they were still working out the kinks. So our food wasn't as hot as it should be. But we politely informed them, and they gave us complimentary kunafeh, which was so crazy delicious. Everything was really tasty, but that kunafeh was the stand-out. Great customer service. Will definitely come back.
author: Oliver S.

description: Khamsa is an absolute gem! Every morsel of food I tried was delicious, bursting with flavor and spice. My lunch was very vegetable forward - the sweet potato tagine is not to be missed - though the calamari I tried was worth coming back for. The eggplant dip and mustard greens were also standouts (you could skip the cauliflower). The space is beautifully designed, modern yet pulling in classic Moroccan details. And so far, one can walk in for lunch without a moment's wait. I can't wait to return.
author: Lena B.

description: The Moroccan lemonade is the best I've ever had in my life. Pretty heavy on the meat aide but everything was delicious.
author: Mai H.

description: Best lamb tagine I've ever tasted and I've been eating Moroccan food for more than 10 years
author: Ken C.

description: Omg. Loved it. The veg items. The dessert & the service! Sat at the bar. We'll be back. Met 1 of the 2 owners - a sweetheart (Adil)!
author: Gernaut A.

description: We really enjoyed this restaurant! Beautiful space, great menu, delicious food, friendly service, and reasonable prices for the quality... Will be coming again for sure!
author: Tarif A.

description: the atmosphere is nice - perfect for a date - and the staff is doing its best to make the experience great. the food is good but not exceptional. was expecting better for this price.
author: Ruben K.

description: This is a Moroccan/Mediterranean/Greek style restaurant with fresh ingredients, great flavors, and perfectly cooked food.  We had lamb, chicken, and fish and all were excellent.  Interesting small wine list, and pleasant informal décor.
author: Steve J.

description: Most authentic Moroccan food I had so far in the city! I had the zaalok and the vegetarian tajine - both were flavorful and tasted fresh! Service is great as well - if they keep up with the quality of the food I believe this to become a very popular, "destination" restaurant.
author: VIORICA C.
